title: Rewrite $$2$$ As a Fraction Using the LCD.

title: Rewrite $$2$$ As a Fraction Using the LCD.
text: By subtracting the numerators and placing the difference over the common denominator, we can rewrite $$\frac{4x-3}{x-3}-\frac{2\left(x-3\right)}{x-3}$$ as $$\frac{4x-3-2\left(x-3\right)}{x-3}$$.

title: Use the Critical Points to Divide the Number Line into Intervals.
text: Given that the $$x=\frac{-3}{2}$$ and $$x=3$$ are the two critical points, we can divide the number line into three intervals, namely, $$(-\infty,\frac{-3}{2})$$, $$(\frac{-3}{2},3)$$ and $$(3,\infty)$$.

title: Test a Value in Each Interval.

title: Determine the Intervals Where the Inequality is Correct.

title: Determine the Critical Points Where the Inequality is Correct
text: The critical point $$x=3$$ makes the denominator $$0$$, so it must be excluded from the solution and we mark it with a parenthesis.\nThe critical point $$x=\frac{-3}{2}$$ makes the whole rational expression $$0$$. The inequality requires that the rational expression be greater than or equal to $$0$$. So, $$\frac{-3}{2}$$ is part of the solution and we will mark it with a bracket.
